.751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis project presents and utilizes YAML Paths, which are a powerful, intuitive\nmeans of identifying one \u003cem\u003eor more\u003c/em\u003e nodes within \u003ca href=\"https://yaml.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eYAML\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/voxpupuli/hiera-eyaml\"\u003eEYAML\u003c/a\u003e, or compatible data structures\nlike \u003ca href=\"https://www.json.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eJSON\u003c/a\u003e.  Both dot-notation (inspired by\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/puppetlabs/hiera\"\u003eHiera\u003c/a\u003e) and forward-slash-notation\n(influenced by \u003ca href=\"https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_xpath.asp\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eXPath\u003c/a\u003e) are\nsupported.  The \u003ca href=\"#libraries\"\u003elibraries\u003c/a\u003e (modules) and several \u003ca href=\"#command-line-tools\"\u003ecommand-line tool\nimplementations\u003c/a\u003e are provided.  With these, you can build\nYAML Path support right into your own application or easily use its capabilities\nright away from the command-line to retrieve, update, merge, validate, and scan\nYAML/JSON/Compatible data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis implementation of YAML Path is a \u003cem\u003equery language\u003c/em\u003e in addition to a \u003cem\u003enode\ndescriptor\u003c/em\u003e.  With it, you can describe or select a single precise node or\nsearch for any number of nodes that match some criteria.  Keys, values,\nelements, anchors, and aliases can all be searched at any number of levels\nwithin the data structure using the same query.  Collectors can also be used to\ngather and further select from otherwise disparate parts of the source data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki\"\u003eproject Wiki\u003c/a\u003e provides a\ndeeper dive into these concepts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eIllustration\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-illustration\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo illustrate some of these concepts, consider these samples:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-yaml notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"---\nhash:\n  child_attr:\n    key: 5280\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e---\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003ehash\u003c/span\u003e:\n  \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003echild_attr\u003c/span\u003e:\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003ekey\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e5280\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis value, \u003ccode\u003e5280\u003c/code\u003e, can be identified via YAML Path as any of:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ehash.child_attr.key\u003c/code\u003e (dot-notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ehash.child_attr[.=key]\u003c/code\u003e (search all child keys for one named, \u003ccode\u003ekey\u003c/code\u003e, and\nyield its value)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e/hash/child_attr/key\u003c/code\u003e (same as 1 but in forward-slash notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e/hash/child_attr[.=key]\u003c/code\u003e (same as 2 but in forward-slash notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-yaml notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"---\naliases:\n  - \u0026amp;first_anchor Simple string value\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e---\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003ealiases\u003c/span\u003e:\n  \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e- \u0026amp;first_anchor Simple string value\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWith YAML Path, you can select this anchored value by any of these equivalent\nexpressions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases[0]\u003c/code\u003e (explicit array element number)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases.0\u003c/code\u003e (implicit array element number in dot-notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases[\u0026amp;first_anchor]\u003c/code\u003e (search by Anchor name)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases[.^Simple]\u003c/code\u003e (search for any elements starting with \"Simple\")\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases[.%string]\u003c/code\u003e (search for any elements containing \"string\")\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases[.$value]\u003c/code\u003e (search for any elements ending with \"value\")\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ealiases[.=~/^(\\b[Ss][a-z]+\\s){2}[a-z]+$/]\u003c/code\u003e (search for any elements matching\na complex Python Regular Expression, which happens to match the example)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e/aliases[0]\u003c/code\u003e (same as 1 but in forward-slash notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e/aliases/0\u003c/code\u003e (same as 2 but in forward-slash notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e/aliases[\u0026amp;first_anchor]\u003c/code\u003e (same as 3 but in forward-slash notation)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-yaml notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"---\nusers:\n  - name: User One\n    password: ENC[PKCS7,MIIBiQY...Jk==]\n    roles:\n      - Writers\n  - name: User Two\n    password: ENC[PKCS7,MIIBiQY...vF==]\n    roles:\n      - Power Users\n      - Editors\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e---\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003eusers\u003c/span\u003e:\n  - \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003ename\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003eUser One\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003epassword\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003eENC[PKCS7,MIIBiQY...Jk==]\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003eroles\u003c/span\u003e:\n      - \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003eWriters\u003c/span\u003e\n  - \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003ename\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003eUser Two\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003epassword\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003eENC[PKCS7,MIIBiQY...vF==]\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003eroles\u003c/span\u003e:\n      - \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003ePower Users\u003c/span\u003e\n      - \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003eEditors\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWith an example like this, YAML Path enables:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eselection of single nodes: \u003ccode\u003e/users/0/roles/0\u003c/code\u003e = \u003ccode\u003eWriters\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eall children nodes of any given parent: \u003ccode\u003e/users/1/roles\u003c/code\u003e =\n\u003ccode\u003e[\"Power Users\", \"Editors\"]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003esearching by a child attribute: \u003ccode\u003e/users[name=\"User One\"]/password\u003c/code\u003e =\n\u003ccode\u003eSome decrypted value, provided you have the appropriate EYAML keys\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003epass-through selections against arrays-of-hashes: \u003ccode\u003e/users/roles\u003c/code\u003e =\n\u003ccode\u003e[\"Writers\"]\\n[\"Power Users\", \"Editors\"]\u003c/code\u003e (each user's list of roles are a\nseparate result)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ecollection of disparate results: \u003ccode\u003e(/users/name)\u003c/code\u003e =\n\u003ccode\u003e[\"User One\", \"User Two\"]\u003c/code\u003e (all names appear in a single result instead of\none per line)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor a deeper exploration of YAML Path's capabilities, please visit the\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki\"\u003eproject Wiki\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eSupported YAML Path Segments\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-supported-yaml-path-segments\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Supported YAML Path Segments\" href=\"#supported-yaml-path-segments\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA YAML Path \u003cem\u003esegment\u003c/em\u003e is the text between separators which identifies zero or\nmore parent or leaf nodes within the data structure.  For dot-notation, a path\nlike \u003ccode\u003ehash.key\u003c/code\u003e identifies two segments:  \u003ccode\u003ehash\u003c/code\u003e (a parent node) and \u003ccode\u003ekey\u003c/code\u003e (a\nleaf node).  The same path in forward-slash notation would be:  \u003ccode\u003e/hash/key\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYAML Path understands these segment types:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTop-level Hash key selection: \u003ccode\u003ekey\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExplicit top-level array element selection: \u003ccode\u003e[#]\u003c/code\u003e where \u003ccode\u003e#\u003c/code\u003e is the zero-based\nelement number; \u003ccode\u003e#\u003c/code\u003e can also be negative, causing the element to be selected\nfrom the end of the Array\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImplicit array element selection \u003cstrong\u003eor\u003c/strong\u003e numbered hash key selection: \u003ccode\u003e#\u003c/code\u003e\nwhere \u003ccode\u003e#\u003c/code\u003e is the 0-based element number \u003cstrong\u003eor\u003c/strong\u003e exact name of a hash key which\nis itself a number\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTop-level (Hash) Anchor lookups: \u003ccode\u003e\u0026amp;anchor_name\u003c/code\u003e (the \u003ccode\u003e\u0026amp;\u003c/code\u003e is required to\nindicate you are seeking an Anchor by name)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHash sub-keys:  \u003ccode\u003ehash.child.key\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e/hash/child/key\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDemarcation for dotted Hash keys:  \u003ccode\u003ehash.'dotted.child.key'\u003c/code\u003e or\n\u003ccode\u003ehash.\"dotted.child.key\"\u003c/code\u003e (not necessary when using forward-slash notation,\n\u003ccode\u003e/hash/dotted.child.key\u003c/code\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNamed Array element selection:  \u003ccode\u003earray[#]\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003earray.#\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e/array[#]\u003c/code\u003e, or\n\u003ccode\u003e/array/#\u003c/code\u003e where \u003ccode\u003earray\u003c/code\u003e is the name of the Hash key containing Array data\nand \u003ccode\u003e#\u003c/code\u003e is the 0-based element number\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAnchor lookups in named Arrays:  \u003ccode\u003earray[\u0026amp;anchor_name]\u003c/code\u003e  where \u003ccode\u003earray\u003c/code\u003e is the\nname of the Hash key containing Array data and both of the \u003ccode\u003e[]\u003c/code\u003e pair and \u003ccode\u003e\u0026amp;\u003c/code\u003e\nare required to indicate you are seeking an Anchor by name within an Array\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eArray slicing: \u003ccode\u003earray[start#:stop#]\u003c/code\u003e where \u003ccode\u003estart#\u003c/code\u003e is the first inclusive,\nzero-based element and \u003ccode\u003estop#\u003c/code\u003e is the last exclusive element to select;\neither or both can be negative, causing the elements to be selected from the\nend of the Array; when \u003ccode\u003estart#\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003estop#\u003c/code\u003e are identical, it is the same as\n\u003ccode\u003earray[start#]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHash slicing: \u003ccode\u003ehash[min:max]\u003c/code\u003e where \u003ccode\u003emin\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003emax\u003c/code\u003e are alphanumeric terms\nbetween which the Hash's keys are compared\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEscape symbol recognition:  \u003ccode\u003ehash.dotted\\.child\\.key\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003e/hash/whacked\\/child\\/key\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003ekeys_with_\\\\slashes\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHash attribute searches (which can return zero or more matches):\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExact match:  \u003ccode\u003ehash[name=admin]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStarts With match:  \u003ccode\u003ehash[name^adm]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnds With match:  \u003ccode\u003ehash[name$min]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eContains match:  \u003ccode\u003ehash[name%dmi]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLess Than match: \u003ccode\u003ehash[access_level\u0026lt;500]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGreater Than match: \u003ccode\u003ehash[access_level\u0026gt;0]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLess Than or Equal match: \u003ccode\u003ehash[access_level\u0026lt;=100]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGreater Than or Equal match: \u003ccode\u003ehash[access_level\u0026gt;=0]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePython Regular Expression\u003c/a\u003e\nmatches: \u003ccode\u003ehash[access_level=~/^\\D+$/]\u003c/code\u003e (the \u003ccode\u003e/\u003c/code\u003e Regular\nExpression delimiter can be substituted for any character you need, except\nwhite-space; note that \u003ccode\u003e/\u003c/code\u003e does not interfere with forward-slash notation\n\u003cem\u003eand it does not need to be escaped\u003c/em\u003e because the entire search expression is\ncontained within a \u003ccode\u003e[]\u003c/code\u003e pair)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInvert any match with \u003ccode\u003e!\u003c/code\u003e, like: \u003ccode\u003ehash[name!=admin]\u003c/code\u003e or even\n\u003ccode\u003ehash[!name=admin]\u003c/code\u003e (the former syntax is used when YAML Paths are\nstringified but both forms are equivalent)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDemarcate and/or escape expression operands, like:\n\u003ccode\u003ehash[full\\ name=\"Some User\\'s Name\"]\u003c/code\u003e (note that embedded, single \u003ccode\u003e'\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003e\"\u003c/code\u003e must be escaped lest they be deemed unmatched demarcation pairings)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMulti-level matching: \u003ccode\u003ehash[name%admin].pass[encrypted!^ENC\\[]\u003c/code\u003e or\n\u003ccode\u003e/hash[name%admin]/pass[encrypted!^ENC\\[]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDescendent node searches:\n\u003ccode\u003estructure[has.descendant.with=something].has.another.field\u003c/code\u003e or\n\u003ccode\u003e/structure[/has/descendant/with=something]/has/another/field\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eArray element searches with all of the search methods above via \u003ccode\u003e.\u003c/code\u003e (yields\nany matching elements): \u003ccode\u003earray[.\u0026gt;9000]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHash key-name searches with all of the search methods above via \u003ccode\u003e.\u003c/code\u003e (yields\ntheir values, not the keys themselves): \u003ccode\u003ehash[.^app_]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eArray-of-Hashes Pass-Through Selection:  Omit a selector for the elements of\nan Array-of-Hashes and all matching Hash attributes at that level will be\nyielded (or searched when there is more to the path).  For example,\n\u003ccode\u003ewarriors[1].power_level\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e/warriors[1]/power_level\u003c/code\u003e will return the\npower_level attribute of only the second Hash in an Array-of-Hashes while\n\u003ccode\u003ewarriors.power_level\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e/warriors/power_level\u003c/code\u003e will return the power_level\nattribute of every Hash in the same Array-of-Hashes.  Of course these results\ncan be filtered in multiple ways, like \u003ccode\u003ewarriors[power_level\u0026gt;9000]\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003e/warriors[power_level\u0026gt;9000]\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ewarriors.power_level[.\u0026gt;9000]\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003e/warriors/power_level[.\u0026gt;9000]\u003c/code\u003e all yield only the power_level from \u003cem\u003eall\u003c/em\u003e\nwarriors with power_levels over 9,000 within the same array of warrior hashes.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUnordered Set value accessing and searching with all above search methods.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWildcard Searches: The \u003ccode\u003e*\u003c/code\u003e symbol can be used as shorthand for the \u003ccode\u003e[]\u003c/code\u003e\nsearch operator against text keys and values: \u003ccode\u003e/warriors/name/Go*\u003c/code\u003e; it also\nreturns every immediate child, regardless its key or value.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeep Traversals:  The \u003ccode\u003e**\u003c/code\u003e symbol pair deeply traverses the document:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen it is the last or only segment of a YAML Path, it selects every leaf\nnode from the remainder of the document's tree: \u003ccode\u003e/shows/**\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen another segment follows, it matches every node within the remainder\nof the document's tree for which the following (and subsequent) segments\nmatch: \u003ccode\u003e/shows/**/name/Star*\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSearch Keywords:  Advanced search capabilities not otherwise possible using\nother YAML Path segments.  Taking the form of \u003ccode\u003e[KEYWORD(PARAMETERS)]\u003c/code\u003e, these\nkeywords are\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki/Search-Keywords\"\u003edeeply explored on the Wiki\u003c/a\u003e\nand include:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[distinct(NAME)]\u003c/code\u003e: Match exactly one of every value within collections,\ndiscarding duplicates; i.e.:  [1, 2, 2, 3] has distinct values, [1, 2, 3]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[has_child(NAME)]\u003c/code\u003e: Match nodes having a named child key\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[max([NAME])]\u003c/code\u003e: Match nodes having the maximum value\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[min([NAME])]\u003c/code\u003e: Match nodes having the minimum value\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[name()]\u003c/code\u003e: Match only the name of the present node, discarding all\nchildren\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[parent([STEPS])]\u003c/code\u003e, Step up 1-N levels in the document from the present\nnode\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[unique(NAME)]\u003c/code\u003e: Match only values which have no duplicates within\ncollections; i.e.:  [1, 2, 2, 3] has unique values, [1, 3]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCollectors:  Placing any portion of the YAML Path within parenthesis defines a\nvirtual list collector, like \u003ccode\u003e(YAML Path)\u003c/code\u003e; concatenation, exclusion, and\nintersection operators are supported -- \u003ccode\u003e+\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e-\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003e\u0026amp;\u003c/code\u003e, respectively --\nalong with nesting, like \u003ccode\u003e(...)-((...)+(...))\u0026amp;(...)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eComplex combinations:\n\u003ccode\u003esome::deep.hierarchy[with!=\"\"].'any.valid'[.=~/(yaml|json)/][data%structure].or.complexity[4].2\u003c/code\u003e\nor \u003ccode\u003e/some::deep/hierarchy[with!=\"\"]/any*.*valid[.=~/(yaml|json)/][data%structure]/or/compl*xity[4]/2/**\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis implementation of YAML Path encourages creativity.  Use whichever notation\nand segment types that make the most sense to you in each application.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki/Segments-of-a-YAML-Path\"\u003eproject Wiki provides more illustrative details of YAML Path Segments\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstalling\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-installing\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Installing\" href=\"#installing\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSome OS distributions offer some versions of yamlpath -- and its dependencies\n-- via packages.  While these versions of yamlpath are often outdated, they can\nbe convenient to install using your OS' native package manager (\u003ccode\u003eapt\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eyum\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003enpm\u003c/code\u003e, and such).  Otherwise, Python's own package manager \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e will always\noffer the latest version of yamlpath and -- even better -- can be isolated to\nephemeral or longer-lasting virtual Python environments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eRequirements\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-requirements\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Requirements\" href=\"#requirements\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis project requires \u003ca href=\"https://www.python.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePython\u003c/a\u003e 3.  It is rigorously\ntested against Pythons 3.7 through 3.11 (support for Python 3.6 was dropped\n10 FEB 2024).  Most operating systems and distributions have access to Python\n3 even if only Python 2 -- or no Python, at all -- came pre-installed.  It is\ngenerally safe to have more than one version of Python on your system at the\nsame time, especially when using\n\u003ca href=\"https://docs.python.org/3/library/venv.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003evirtual Python environments\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e depends on \u003cem\u003eruamel.yaml\u003c/em\u003e (derived from and greatly extending PyYAML)\nand \u003cem\u003epython-dateutil\u003c/em\u003e.  When using OS-native packages or \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e, you do not need\nto pre-install these libraries yourself except under extraordinary\ncircumstances like using very old versions of \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e or its own dependency,\n\u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eUsing pip\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-using-pip\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Using pip\" href=\"#using-pip\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLike most others, this Python project is published to \u003ca href=\"https://pypi.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePyPI\u003c/a\u003e\nso that it can be easily installed via Python's \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e command (or its\nversion-specific \u003ccode\u003epip3\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003epip3.7\u003c/code\u003e, and such depending on how your Python was\ninstalled).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePython's \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e command is ever-changing.  It is updated very frequently.  This\ncommand further depends on other libraries to do its job, namely \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e.\nIt so happens that \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e is also updated very frequently.  Both of these\nare separate from Python itself, despite versions of them being pre-installed\nwith Python.  It is your responsibility to keep \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e\nup-to-date.  When \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e or \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e become outdated, \u003cem\u003eyou will experience\nerrors\u003c/em\u003e when trying to install newer Python packages like \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e \u003cstrong\u003eunless\nyou preinstall such packages' dependencies\u003c/strong\u003e.  In the case of \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e, this\nmeans you'd need to preinstall \u003cem\u003eruamel.yaml\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003epython-dateutil\u003c/em\u003e if you\ncannot or choose not to upgrade \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and/or \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAs long as your \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e are up-to-date, installing \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e is\nas simple as a single command (the \"3.7\" suffix to the \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e command is\noptional, depending on how your Python 3 was installed):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"pip3.7 install yamlpath\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epip3.7 install yamlpath\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eVery Old Versions of pip or its setuptools Dependency\u003c/h4\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-very-old-versions-of-pip-or-its-setuptools-dependency\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Very Old Versions of pip or its setuptools Dependency\" href=\"#very-old-versions-of-pip-or-its-setuptools-dependency\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVery old versions of Python 3 ship with seriously outdated versions of \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and\nits \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e dependency.  When using versions of \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e older than \u003cstrong\u003e18.1\u003c/strong\u003e\nor \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e older than version \u003cstrong\u003e46.4.0\u003c/strong\u003e, you will not be able to install\n\u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e with a single command.  In this case, you have two options:  either\npre-install \u003cem\u003eruamel.yaml\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003epython-dateutil\u003c/em\u003e before installing \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e or\nupdate \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and/or \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e to at least the minimum required versions so\n\u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e can auto-determine and install dependencies.  This issue is not unique to\n\u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUpgrading \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e is trivially simple as long as you have\nsufficient access rights to do so on your local machine.  Depending on your\nsituation, you may need to prefix these with \u003ccode\u003esudo\u003c/code\u003e and/or you may need to\nsubstitute \u003ccode\u003epython3\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003epip3\u003c/code\u003e for \u003ccode\u003epython\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e, or even \u003ccode\u003epython3.7\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003epip3.7\u003c/code\u003e (or another specific version of Python 3), respectively.  To reiterate\nthat this project requires Python 3, these sample commands will be\ndemonstrated using such prefixes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"python3.7 -m pip install --upgrade pip\npip3.7 install --upgrade setuptools\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epython3.7 -m pip install --upgrade pip\npip3.7 install --upgrade setuptools\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen you cannot or will not update \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e or \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e, just pre-install\n\u003cem\u003eruamel.yaml\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003epython-dateutil\u003c/em\u003e before yamlpath.  Each must be installed\nseparately and in order, like this (you \u003cstrong\u003ecannot\u003c/strong\u003e combine these installations\ninto a single command):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"pip3.7 install ruamel.yaml python-dateutil\npip3.7 install yamlpath\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epip3.7 install ruamel.yaml python-dateutil\npip3.7 install yamlpath\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe downside to choosing this manual installation path is that you may end up\nwith an incompatible version of \u003cem\u003eruamel.yaml\u003c/em\u003e or \u003cem\u003epython-dateutil\u003c/em\u003e.  This will\nmanifest either as an inability to install \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e at all, or only certain\nversions of \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e, or \u003cem\u003eyamlpath\u003c/em\u003e may experience unexpected errors caused\nby the incompatible code.  For the best experience, you are strongly encouraged\nto just keep \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e and \u003cem\u003esetuptools\u003c/em\u003e up-to-date, particularly as a routine part\nof installing any new Python packages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstalling EYAML (Optional)\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-installing-eyaml-optional\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Installing EYAML (Optional)\" href=\"#installing-eyaml-optional\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eEYAML support is entirely optional.  You do not need EYAML to use YAML Path.\nThat YAML Path supports EYAML is a service to a substantial audience:  Puppet\nusers.  At the time of this writing, EYAML (classified as a Hiera\nback-end/plug-in) is available only as a Ruby Gem.  That said, it provides a\ncommand-line tool, \u003ccode\u003eeyaml\u003c/code\u003e, which can be employed by this otherwise Python\nproject.  To enjoy EYAML support, install compatible versions of ruby and\nrubygems, then execute:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"gem install hiera-eyaml\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003egem install hiera-eyaml\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf this puts the \u003ccode\u003eeyaml\u003c/code\u003e command on your system \u003ccode\u003ePATH\u003c/code\u003e, nothing more need be\ndone apart from generating or obtaining your encryption keys.  Otherwise, you\ncan tell YAML Path library and tools where to find the \u003ccode\u003eeyaml\u003c/code\u003e command.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eBased on ruamel.yaml\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-based-on-ruamelyaml\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Based on ruamel.yaml\" href=\"#based-on-ruamelyaml\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn order to support the best available YAML editing capability (so called,\nround-trip editing with support for comment preservation), this project is based\non \u003ca href=\"https://sourceforge.net/projects/ruamel-yaml/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eruamel.yaml\u003c/a\u003e for\nPython 3.  While ruamel.yaml is based on PyYAML --\nPython's \"standard\" YAML library -- ruamel.yaml is \u003ca href=\"https://yaml.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pyyaml.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eobjectively better than\nPyYAML\u003c/a\u003e, which lacks critical\nround-trip editing capabilities as well as up-to-date YAML/Compatible data\nparsing capabilities (at the time of this writing).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eShould PyYAML ever merge with -- or at least, catch up with -- ruamel.yaml, this\nproject can be (lightly) adapted to depend on it, instead.  These conversations\nmay offer some insight into when or whether this might happen:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/31\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/yaml/pyyaml/issues/31/hovercard\"\u003eIs this time to pass the baton?\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/46\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/yaml/pyyaml/issues/46/hovercard\"\u003eRebase off ruamel? - many new valuable features\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe Files of This Project\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-the-files-of-this-project\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: The Files of This Project\" href=\"#the-files-of-this-project\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis repository contains:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGenerally-useful Python library files.  These contain the reusable core of\nthis project's YAML Path capabilities.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSome implementations of those libraries, exhibiting their capabilities and\nsimple-to-use APIs as command-line tools.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eVarious support, documentation, and build files.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eCommand-Line Tools\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-command-line-tools\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Command-Line Tools\" href=\"#command-line-tools\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis project provides some command-line tool implementations which utilize YAML\nPath.  For some use-case examples of these tools,\n\u003ca href=\"#basic-usage--command-line-tools\"\u003esee below\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe supplied command-line tools include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/wwkimball/yamlpath/blob/master/yamlpath/commands/eyaml_rotate_keys.py\"\u003eeyaml-rotate-keys\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"usage: eyaml-rotate-keys [-h] [-V] [-d | -v | -q] [-b] [-x EYAML]\n                         -i OLDPRIVATEKEY -c OLDPUBLICKEY\n                         -r NEWPRIVATEKEY -u NEWPUBLICKEY\n                         YAML_FILE [YAML_FILE ...]\n\nRotates the encryption keys used for all EYAML values within a set of YAML\nfiles, decrypting with old keys and re-encrypting using replacement keys.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             one or more YAML files containing EYAML values\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except errors\n  -b, --backup          save a backup of each modified YAML_FILE with an extra\n                        .bak file-extension\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n\nEYAML_KEYS:\n  All key arguments are required\n\n  -r NEWPRIVATEKEY, --newprivatekey NEWPRIVATEKEY\n                        the new EYAML private key\n  -u NEWPUBLICKEY, --newpublickey NEWPUBLICKEY\n                        the new EYAML public key\n  -i OLDPRIVATEKEY, --oldprivatekey OLDPRIVATEKEY\n                        the old EYAML private key\n  -c OLDPUBLICKEY, --oldpublickey OLDPUBLICKEY\n                        the old EYAML public key\n\nAny YAML_FILEs lacking EYAML values will not be modified (or backed up, even\nwhen -b/--backup is specified).\"\u003e\u003cpre lang=\"text\" class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eusage: eyaml-rotate-keys [-h] [-V] [-d | -v | -q] [-b] [-x EYAML]\n                         -i OLDPRIVATEKEY -c OLDPUBLICKEY\n                         -r NEWPRIVATEKEY -u NEWPUBLICKEY\n                         YAML_FILE [YAML_FILE ...]\n\nRotates the encryption keys used for all EYAML values within a set of YAML\nfiles, decrypting with old keys and re-encrypting using replacement keys.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             one or more YAML files containing EYAML values\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except errors\n  -b, --backup          save a backup of each modified YAML_FILE with an extra\n                        .bak file-extension\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n\nEYAML_KEYS:\n  All key arguments are required\n\n  -r NEWPRIVATEKEY, --newprivatekey NEWPRIVATEKEY\n                        the new EYAML private key\n  -u NEWPUBLICKEY, --newpublickey NEWPUBLICKEY\n                        the new EYAML public key\n  -i OLDPRIVATEKEY, --oldprivatekey OLDPRIVATEKEY\n                        the old EYAML private key\n  -c OLDPUBLICKEY, --oldpublickey OLDPUBLICKEY\n                        the old EYAML public key\n\nAny YAML_FILEs lacking EYAML values will not be modified (or backed up, even\nwhen -b/--backup is specified).\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/wwkimball/yamlpath/blob/master/yamlpath/commands/yaml_diff.py\"\u003eyaml-diff\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"usage: yaml-diff [-h] [-V] [-a] [-s | -o]\n                 [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']] [-x EYAML]\n                 [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-E] [-d | -v | -q]\n                 YAML_FILE YAML_FILE\n\nCalculate the functional difference between two YAML/JSON/Compatible\ndocuments. Immaterial differences (which YAML/JSON parsers discard) are\nignored. EYAML can be employed to compare encrypted values.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             exactly two YAML/JSON/compatible files to compare; use\n                        - to read one document from STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -a, --sync-arrays     Synchronize array elements before comparing them,\n                        resulting only in ADD, DELETE, and SAME differences\n                        (no CHANGEs because the positions of elements are\n                        disregarded); Array-of-Hash elements must completely\n                        and perfectly match or they will be deemed additions\n                        or deletions\n  -s, --same            Show all nodes which are the same in addition to\n                        differences\n  -o, --onlysame        Show only nodes which are the same, still reporting\n                        that differences exist -- when they do -- with an\n                        exit-state of 1\n  -t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash'], --pathsep ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']\n                        indicate which YAML Path separator to use when\n                        rendering results; default=dot\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except system errors\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults.\n  Both keys must be set either here or in your system or user EYAML\n  configuration file when using EYAML.\n\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n  -E, --ignore-eyaml-values\n                        Do not use EYAML to compare encrypted data; rather,\n                        treat ENC[...] values as regular strings\n\nOnly one YAML_FILE may be the - pseudo-file for reading from STDIN. For more\ninformation about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath.\"\u003e\u003cpre lang=\"text\" class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eusage: yaml-diff [-h] [-V] [-a] [-s | -o]\n                 [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']] [-x EYAML]\n                 [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-E] [-d | -v | -q]\n                 YAML_FILE YAML_FILE\n\nCalculate the functional difference between two YAML/JSON/Compatible\ndocuments. Immaterial differences (which YAML/JSON parsers discard) are\nignored. EYAML can be employed to compare encrypted values.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             exactly two YAML/JSON/compatible files to compare; use\n                        - to read one document from STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -a, --sync-arrays     Synchronize array elements before comparing them,\n                        resulting only in ADD, DELETE, and SAME differences\n                        (no CHANGEs because the positions of elements are\n                        disregarded); Array-of-Hash elements must completely\n                        and perfectly match or they will be deemed additions\n                        or deletions\n  -s, --same            Show all nodes which are the same in addition to\n                        differences\n  -o, --onlysame        Show only nodes which are the same, still reporting\n                        that differences exist -- when they do -- with an\n                        exit-state of 1\n  -t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash'], --pathsep ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']\n                        indicate which YAML Path separator to use when\n                        rendering results; default=dot\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except system errors\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults.\n  Both keys must be set either here or in your system or user EYAML\n  configuration file when using EYAML.\n\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n  -E, --ignore-eyaml-values\n                        Do not use EYAML to compare encrypted data; rather,\n                        treat ENC[...] values as regular strings\n\nOnly one YAML_FILE may be the - pseudo-file for reading from STDIN. For more\ninformation about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath.\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/wwkimball/yamlpath/blob/master/yamlpath/commands/yaml_get.py\"\u003eyaml-get\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"usage: yaml-get [-h] [-V] -p YAML_PATH\n                [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']] [-S] [-x EYAML]\n                [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-d | -v | -q]\n                [YAML_FILE]\n\nRetrieves one or more values from a YAML/JSON/Compatible file at a specified\nYAML Path. Output is printed to STDOUT, one line per result. When a result is\na complex data-type (Array or Hash), a JSON dump is produced to represent it.\nEYAML can be employed to decrypt the values.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             the YAML file to query; omit or use - to read from\n                        STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash'], --pathsep ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']\n                        indicate which YAML Path separator to use when\n                        rendering results; default=dot\n  -S, --nostdin         Do not implicitly read from STDIN, even when YAML_FILE\n                        is not set and the session is non-TTY\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except errors\n\nrequired settings:\n  -p YAML_PATH, --query YAML_PATH\n                        YAML Path to query\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults.\n  Both keys must be set either here or in your system or user EYAML\n  configuration file when using EYAML.\n\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n\nFor more information about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath.\"\u003e\u003cpre lang=\"text\" class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eusage: yaml-get [-h] [-V] -p YAML_PATH\n                [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']] [-S] [-x EYAML]\n                [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-d | -v | -q]\n                [YAML_FILE]\n\nRetrieves one or more values from a YAML/JSON/Compatible file at a specified\nYAML Path. Output is printed to STDOUT, one line per result. When a result is\na complex data-type (Array or Hash), a JSON dump is produced to represent it.\nEYAML can be employed to decrypt the values.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             the YAML Any file, including input from STDIN, may be a\n            multi-document YAML or JSON file.\n\n            For more information about YAML Paths, please visit\n            https://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath.\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/wwkimball/yamlpath/blob/master/yamlpath/commands/yaml_paths.py\"\u003eyaml-paths\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"usage: yaml-paths [-h] [-V] -s EXPRESSION [-c EXPRESSION] [-m] [-L] [-F] [-X]\n                  [-P] [-n] [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']]\n                  [-i | -k | -K] [-a] [-A | -Y | -y | -l] [-e] [-x EYAML]\n                  [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-S] [-d | -v | -q]\n                  [YAML_FILE [YAML_FILE ...]]\n\nReturns zero or more YAML Paths indicating where in given YAML/JSON/Compatible\ndata one or more search expressions match. Values, keys, and/or anchors can be\nsearched. EYAML can be employed to search encrypted values.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             one or more YAML files to search; omit or use - to\n                        read from STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -c EXPRESSION, --except EXPRESSION\n                        except results matching this search expression; can be\n                        set more than once\n  -m, --expand          expand matching parent nodes to list all permissible\n                        child leaf nodes (see \u0026quot;reference handling options\u0026quot; for\n                        restrictions)\n  -t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash'], --pathsep ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']\n                        indicate which YAML Path separator to use when\n                        rendering results; default=dot\n  -a, --refnames        also search the names of \u0026amp;anchor and *alias references\n  -S, --nostdin         Do not implicitly read from STDIN, even when there are\n                        no - pseudo-files in YAML_FILEs with a non-TTY session\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all non-result output except errors\n\nrequired settings:\n  -s EXPRESSION, --search EXPRESSION\n                        the search expression; can be set more than once\n\nresult printing options:\n  -L, --values          print the values or elements along with each YAML Path\n                        (complex results are emitted as JSON; use --expand to\n                        emit only simple values)\n  -F, --nofile          omit source file path and name decorators from the\n                        output (applies only when searching multiple files)\n  -X, --noexpression    omit search expression decorators from the output\n  -P, --noyamlpath      omit YAML Paths from the output (useful with --values\n                        or to indicate whether a file has any matches without\n                        printing them all, perhaps especially with\n                        --noexpression)\n  -n, --noescape        omit escape characters from special characters in\n                        printed YAML Paths; this is unsafe for feeding the\n                        resulting YAML Paths into other YAML Path commands\n                        because the symbols that would be escaped have special\n                        meaning to YAML Path processors\n\nkey name searching options:\n  -i, --ignorekeynames  (default) do not search key names\n  -k, --keynames        search key names in addition to values and array\n                        elements\n  -K, --onlykeynames    only search key names (ignore all values and array\n                        elements)\n\nreference handling options:\n  Indicate how to treat anchor and alias references. An anchor is an\n  original, reusable key or value. All aliases become replaced by the\n  anchors they reference when YAML data is read. These options specify how\n  to handle this duplication of keys and values. Note that the default\n  behavior includes all aliased keys but not aliased values.\n\n  -A, --anchorsonly     include only original matching key and value anchors\n                        in results, discarding all aliased keys and values\n                        (including child nodes)\n  -Y, --allowkeyaliases\n                        (default) include matching key aliases, permitting\n                        search traversal into their child nodes\n  -y, --allowvaluealiases\n                        include matching value aliases (does not permit search\n                        traversal into aliased keys)\n  -l, --allowaliases    include all matching key and value aliases\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults.\n  Both keys must be set either here or in your system or user EYAML\n  configuration file when using EYAML.\n\n  -e, --decrypt         decrypt EYAML values in order to search them\n                        (otherwise, search the encrypted blob)\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n\nA search or exception EXPRESSION takes the form of a YAML Path search operator\n-- %, $, =, ^, \u0026gt;, \u0026lt;, \u0026gt;=, \u0026lt;=, =~, or ! -- followed by the search term, omitting\nthe left-hand operand. For more information about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki. Values, keys, and/or anchors can be\nsearched. EYAML can be employed to search encrypted values.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             one or more YAML files to search; omit or use - to\n                        read from STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -c EXPRESSION, --except EXPRESSION\n                        except results matching this search expression; can be set more than once\n\nresult printing options:\n  -L, --values          print the values or elements along with each YAML Path\n                        (complex results are emitted as JSON; use --expand to\n                        emit only simple values)\n  -F, --nofile          omit source file path and name decorators from the\n                        output (applies only when searching multiple files)\n  -X, --noexpression    omit search expression decorators from the output\n  -P, --noyamlpath      omit YAML Paths from the output (useful with --values\n                        or to indicate whether a file has any matches without\n                        printing them all, perhaps especially with\n                        --noexpression)\n  -n, --noescape        omit escape characters from special characters in\n                        printed YAML Paths; An anchor is an\n  original, reusable key or value. All aliases become replaced by the\n  anchors they reference when YAML data is read. These options specify how\n  to handle this duplication of keys and values. Note that the default\n  behavior includes all aliased keys but not aliased values.\n\n  -A, --anchorsonly     include only original matching key and value anchors\n                        in results, discarding all aliased keys and values\n                        (including child nodes)\n  -Y, --allowkeyaliases\n                        (default) include matching key aliases, permitting\n                        search traversal into their child nodes\n  -y, --allowvaluealiases\n                        include matching value aliases (does not permit search\n                        traversal into aliased keys)\n  -l, --allowaliases    include all matching key and value aliases\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults.\n  Both keys must be set either here or in your system or user EYAML\n  configuration file when using EYAML.\n\n  -e, --decrypt         decrypt EYAML values in order to search them\n                        (otherwise, search the encrypted blob)\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n\nA search or exception EXPRESSION takes the form of a YAML Path search operator\n-- %, $, =, ^, \u0026gt;, \u0026lt;, \u0026gt;=, \u0026lt;=, =~, or ! -- followed by the search term, omitting\nthe left-hand operand. For more information about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki. To report issues with this tool or\nto request enhancements, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/issues.\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/wwkimball/yamlpath/blob/master/yamlpath/commands/yaml_set.py\"\u003eyaml-set\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"usage: yaml-set [-h] [-V] -g YAML_PATH\n                [-a VALUE | -A ANCHOR | -f FILE | -i | -R LENGTH | -N | -D]\n                [-F {bare,boolean,default,dquote,float,folded,int,literal,squote}]\n                [-c CHECK] [-s YAML_PATH] [-m] [-b]\n                [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']] [-M CHARS] [-H ANCHOR]\n                [-T TAG] [-e] [-x EYAML] [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-S]\n                [-d | -v | -q]\n                [YAML_FILE]\n\nChanges one or more Scalar values in a YAML/JSON/Compatible document at a\nspecified YAML Path. Matched values can be checked before they are replaced to\nmitigate accidental change. When matching singular results, the value can be\narchived to another key before it is replaced. Further, EYAML can be employed to\nencrypt the new values and/or decrypt an old value before checking it.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             the YAML file to update; omit or use - to read from\n                        STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -F {bare,boolean,default,dquote,float,folded,int,literal,squote}, --format {bare,boolean,default,dquote,float,folded,int,literal,squote}\n                        override automatic formatting of the new value\n  -c CHECK, --check CHECK\n                        check the value before replacing it\n  -s YAML_PATH, --saveto YAML_PATH\n                        save the old value to YAML_PATH before replacing it;\n                        implies --mustexist\n  -m, --mustexist       require that the --change YAML_PATH already exist in\n                        YAML_FILE\n  -b, --backup          save a backup YAML_FILE with an extra .bak file-\n                        extension\n  -t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash'], --pathsep ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']\n                        indicate which YAML Path separator to use when rendering\n                        results; default=dot\n  -M CHARS, --random-from CHARS\n                        characters from which to build a value for --random;\n                        default=all upper- and lower-case letters and all digits\n  -H ANCHOR, --anchor ANCHOR\n                        when --aliasof|-A points to a value which is not already\n                        Anchored, a new Anchor with this name is created;\n                        renames an existing Anchor if already set\n  -T TAG, --tag TAG     assign a custom YAML (data-type) tag to the changed\n                        nodes; can be used without other input options to assign\n                        or change a tag\n  -S, --nostdin         Do not implicitly read from STDIN, even when there is no\n                        YAML_FILE with a non-TTY session\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except errors\n\nrequired settings:\n  -g YAML_PATH, --change YAML_PATH\n                        YAML Path where the target value is found\n\ninput options:\n  -a VALUE, --value VALUE\n                        set the new value from the command-line instead of STDIN\n  -A ANCHOR, --aliasof ANCHOR\n                        set the value as a YAML Alias of an existing Anchor, by\n                        name (merely copies the target value for non-YAML files)\n  -f FILE, --file FILE  read the new value from file (discarding any trailing\n                        new-lines)\n  -i, --stdin           accept the new value from STDIN (best for sensitive\n                        data)\n  -R LENGTH, --random LENGTH\n                        randomly generate a replacement value of a set length\n  -N, --null            sets the value to null\n  -D, --delete          delete rather than change target node(s); implies\n                        --mustexist|-m\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults. You\n  do not need to supply a private key unless you enable --check and the old\n  value is encrypted.\n\n  -e, --eyamlcrypt      encrypt the new value using EYAML\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n\nWhen no changes are made, no backup is created, even when -b/--backup is\nspecified. For more information about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki. To report issues with this tool or\nto request enhancements, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/issues.\"\u003e\u003cpre lang=\"text\" class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eusage: yaml-set [-h] [-V] -g YAML_PATH\n                [-a VALUE | -A ANCHOR | -f FILE | -i | -R LENGTH | -N | -D]\n                [-F {bare,boolean,default,dquote,float,folded,int,literal,squote}]\n                [-c CHECK] [-s YAML_PATH] [-m] [-b]\n                [-t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']] [-M CHARS] [-H ANCHOR]\n                [-T TAG] [-e] [-x EYAML] [-r PRIVATEKEY] [-u PUBLICKEY] [-S]\n                [-d | -v | -q]\n                [YAML_FILE]\n\nChanges one or more Scalar values in a YAML/JSON/Compatible document at a\nspecified YAML Path. Matched values can be checked before they are replaced to\nmitigate accidental change. When matching singular results, the value can be\narchived to another key before it is replaced. Further, EYAML can be employed to\nencrypt the new values and/or decrypt an old value before checking it.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE             the YAML file to update; omit or use - to read from\n                        STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version         show program's version number and exit\n  -F {bare,boolean,default,dquote,float,folded,int,literal,squote}, --format {bare,boolean,default,dquote,float,folded,int,literal,squote}\n                        override automatic formatting of the new value\n  -c CHECK, --check CHECK\n                        check the value before replacing it\n  -s YAML_PATH, --saveto YAML_PATH\n                        save the old value to YAML_PATH before replacing it;\n                        implies --mustexist\n  -m, --mustexist       require that the --change YAML_PATH already exist in\n                        YAML_FILE\n  -b, --backup          save a backup YAML_FILE with an extra .bak file-\n                        extension\n  -t ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash'], --pathsep ['.', '/', 'auto', 'dot', 'fslash']\n                        indicate which YAML Path separator to use when rendering\n                        results; default=dot\n  -M CHARS, --random-from CHARS\n                        characters from which to build a value for --random;\n                        default=all upper- and lower-case letters and all digits\n  -H ANCHOR, --anchor ANCHOR\n                        when --aliasof|-A points to a value which is not already\n                        Anchored, a new Anchor with this name is created;\n                        renames an existing Anchor if already set\n  -T TAG, --tag TAG     assign a custom YAML (data-type) tag to the changed\n                        nodes; can be used without other input options to assign\n                        or change a tag\n  -S, --nostdin         Do not implicitly read from STDIN, even when there is no\n                        YAML_FILE with a non-TTY session\n  -d, --debug           output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose         increase output verbosity\n  -q, --quiet           suppress all output except errors\n\nrequired settings:\n  -g YAML_PATH, --change YAML_PATH\n                        YAML Path where the target value is found\n\ninput options:\n  -a VALUE, --value VALUE\n                        set the new value from the command-line instead of STDIN\n  -A ANCHOR, --aliasof ANCHOR\n                        set the value as a YAML Alias of an existing Anchor, by\n                        name (merely copies the target value for non-YAML files)\n  -f FILE, --file FILE  read the new value from file (discarding any trailing\n                        new-lines)\n  -i, --stdin           accept the new value from STDIN (best for sensitive\n                        data)\n  -R LENGTH, --random LENGTH\n                        randomly generate a replacement value of a set length\n  -N, --null            sets the value to null\n  -D, --delete          delete rather than change target node(s); implies\n                        --mustexist|-m\n\nEYAML options:\n  Left unset, the EYAML keys will default to your system or user defaults. You\n  do not need to supply a private key unless you enable --check and the old\n  value is encrypted.\n\n  -e, --eyamlcrypt      encrypt the new value using EYAML\n  -x EYAML, --eyaml EYAML\n                        the eyaml binary to use when it isn't on the PATH\n  -r PRIVATEKEY, --privatekey PRIVATEKEY\n                        EYAML private key\n  -u PUBLICKEY, --publickey PUBLICKEY\n                        EYAML public key\n\nWhen no changes are made, no backup is created, even when -b/--backup is\nspecified. For more information about YAML Paths, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/wiki. To report issues with this tool or\nto request enhancements, please visit\nhttps://github.com/wwkimball/yamlpath/issues.\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/wwkimball/yamlpath/blob/master/yamlpath/commands/yaml_validate.py\"\u003eyaml-validate\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"usage: yaml-validate [-h] [-V] [-S] [-d | -v | -q] [YAML_FILE [YAML_FILE ...]]\n\nValidate YAML, JSON, and compatible files.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE      one or more single- or multi-document YAML/JSON/compatible\n                 files to validate; omit or use - to read from STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help     show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version  show program's version number and exit\n  -S, --nostdin  Do not implicitly read from STDIN, even when there are no -\n                 pseudo-files in YAML_FILEs with a non-TTY session\n  -d, --debug    output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose  increase output verbosity (show valid documents)\n  -q, --quiet    suppress all output except system errors\n\nExcept when suppressing all report output with --quiet|-q, validation issues\nare printed to STDOUT (not STDERR). Further, the exit-state will report 0 when\nthere are no issues, 1 when there is an issue with the supplied command-line\narguments, or 2 when validation has failed for any document.\"\u003e\u003cpre lang=\"text\" class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eusage: yaml-validate [-h] [-V] [-S] [-d | -v | -q] [YAML_FILE [YAML_FILE ...]]\n\nValidate YAML, JSON, and compatible files.\n\npositional arguments:\n  YAML_FILE      one or more single- or multi-document YAML/JSON/compatible\n                 files to validate; omit or use - to read from STDIN\n\noptional arguments:\n  -h, --help     show this help message and exit\n  -V, --version  show program's version number and exit\n  -S, --nostdin  Do not implicitly read from STDIN, even when there are no -\n                 pseudo-files in YAML_FILEs with a non-TTY session\n  -d, --debug    output debugging details\n  -v, --verbose  increase output verbosity (show valid documents)\n  -q, --quiet    suppress all output except system errors\n\nExcept when suppressing all report output with --quiet|-q, validation issues\nare printed to STDOUT (not STDERR). Further, the exit-state will report 0 when\nthere are no issues, 1 when there is an issue with the supplied command-line\narguments, or 2 when validation has failed for any document.\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"yaml-diff yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eyaml-diff yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOutput is very similar to that of standard GNU diff against text files, except\nit is generated against the \u003cem\u003edata\u003c/em\u003e within the input files.  This excludes\nevaluating purely structural and immaterial differences between them like value\ndemarcation, white-space, and comments.  When you need to evaluate the two\nfiles as if they were just text files, use GNU diff or any of its clones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo see all identical entries along with differences:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"yaml-diff --same yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eyaml-diff --same yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo see \u003cem\u003eonly\u003c/em\u003e entries which are identical between the documents:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"yaml-diff --onlysame yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eyaml-diff --onlysame yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdvanced:  Arrays can be evaluated such that they are synchronized before\nevaluation.  Rather than compare elements by identical index in both\ndocuments -- reporting differences between them as changes and any additional\nelements as additions or deletions -- they can instead be compared by matching\nup all identical elements and then reporting only those values which are unique\nto either document (and optionally identical matches).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"yaml-diff --sync-arrays yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eyaml-diff --sync-arrays yaml_file1.yaml yaml_file2.yaml\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4
